The estimated date when Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage, was believed to have been killed in captivity by Hamas.
The signing date of the US-proposed ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas, which required the return of deceased hostages within 72 hours.
The date when the bodies of Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar were returned to Israel from Gaza, marking a key development in the humanitarian and diplomatic phase of the ceasefire process.

keyTakeAways: Hamas returned the bodies of two deceased Israeli hostages—Arye Zalmanovich and Tamir Adar—on October 22, 2025, following the ceasefire agreement signed on October 9, 2025.
Arye Zalmanovich, aged 85, was the oldest hostage taken by Hamas and died in captivity on November 17, 2023; he was a founding member of Kibbutz Nir Oz and a farmer.
Tamir Adar, aged 38, died defending his kibbutz on October 7, 2023; he was a farmer, educator, and beloved community member.
The bodies were returned to Israel for formal identification and to investigate causes of death at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine.
Hamas has returned 15 of the 28 deceased hostages as per the ceasefire agreement, but Israel and the US express concern that not all bodies may be recoverable due to rubble and lack of information.
A body returned by Hamas was initially misidentified and not an Israeli hostage, indicating challenges in body recovery and verification.
US Vice President JD Vance emphasized that retrieving the bodies is a priority, but acknowledged it is not an overnight process due to logistical and environmental challenges.
The Biden administration and US officials continue to stress the importance of recovering all deceased hostages for family closure and humanitarian reasons.

summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 22, 2025, Hamas returned the bodies of two deceased hostages—Arye Zalmanovich, the oldest hostage taken during the October 7, 2023 attacks, and Tamir Adar, a defender who died in the initial assault—to Israel for identification. Zalmanovich, 85, was a founding member of Kibbutz Nir Oz and a farmer; Adar, 38, died defending his community. The return is part of a US-proposed ceasefire agreement signed on October 9, 2025, which required the return of all deceased hostages within 72 hours. However, challenges remain, including the misidentification of a body and the difficulty of recovering bodies buried under rubble. US Vice President JD Vance acknowledged the difficulty of the process but emphasized the importance of retrieving remains for family closure. The IDF confirmed identification, and Israeli officials expressed deep sorrow for the families of the fallen.
title: Oldest hostage taken by Hamas among two deceased returned to Israel Tuesday
